description.narrative: Capacity development of the Ministry of Amerindian Affairs.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Number of MOAA capacity development plans

comment.narrative: Low capacity of MoAA to plan, manage, and support community development
1. Capacity Development Plan implemented 2. Improved physical infrastructure, human resources capacity and project management process of the special projects unit
Training of 15 Community Development Officers to monitor project and to coordinate delivery of support to projects.

Preparation of resource materials: (i) Handbook on public financial management and accountability for the Ministry of Indigenous People's Affairs (MoIPA); (ii) Training manual on monitoring and evaluation; (iii) Training manual on geographic information systems (GIS), Training of Trainers resource guide for Amerindian village economic development.
Training of personnel of MoIPA, National Toshaos Council (NTC) and Amerindian Village Councils in (i) financial management and management information systems, monitoring and evaluation and GIS.
Training of 161 Community Development Plans Management Teams (CMTs) in project and business management.

32 persons now have capacity to monitor and evaluate projects: including 5 project management staff of the MoIPA , 12 Community Development Officers of the MoIPA, and 15 executive members of the NTC.
More than 50 persons now have competence in public financial management from the MoIPA, NTC and Amerindian Village Councils in Regions 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8 and 10.
78 CMTs now have capacity to manage Amerindian village economic development projects in Regions 1, 2, 7, 8, 9 and 10.

description.narrative: UNDP is supporting the Government of Guyana to strengthen monitoring and implementation of biodiversity-friendly practices in Guyana's gold mining sector to reduce biodiversity loss and maintain ecosystem functionality for the benefit of all Guyanese.
The IRRF is UNDPâ€™s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPâ€™s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of men above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Number of women above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Final Global Environment Facility (GEF) Medium Sized Project ( MSP) Project Document Mainstreaming Biodiversity Management into Mining Concession Framework and Practices in Guyana
Energy - policy, planning and administration

i. Number of actions taken by (such as issuance of enforcement notices, laying of charges or mediation proceedings) in the areas identified through the project as high priority for monitoring and enforcement in small and medium-scale gold mining areas 2. level of coordinating capacity among institutions and non-state actors for enforcement of mining-related environmental practices 3. percentage of total areas identified as high priority for monitoring and enforcement that is being monitored using satellite tracking.

comment.narrative: Number of enforcement and prohibition policies has almost nil effect for small and medium scale mining. Ad-hoc monitoring or compliance checks in response to complaints amount to approximately 4-5 per year

i. Increase in number of compliance actions taken by EPA (such as issuance of enforcement notices, laying of charges or mediation proceedings) by at least 50% over 2013/2014 baseline target of at least 7 per year) 2. At least 75% of total high priority area is being being monitored using satellite tracking.
2. Over 25 persons trained in satellite image interpretation. Laboratory equipment for the Mining School was ordered from an overseas supplier.

1.A local consultancy firm - Environmental Management Consultants - is building the capacity of regulatory agencies for the monitoring and enforcement of mining regulations. 2. Priority hotspot areas for monitoring of biodiversity were identfied. 3. The University of Guyana is undertaking a review of the curriculum of the Guyana Mining School, and train at least six trainers to conduct seminars for small and medium-scale miners.

1. 50% increase in number of compliance actions taken by EPA over 2013/2014 baseline target of at least 7 per year. 2. 50% increase in number of collaborative meetings and monitoring visits for enforcement of mining-related environmental practices. 3. At least 75% of total high priority area is being monitored using satellite tracking. 4. At least 5 courses or seminars that adequately incorporated biodiversity considerations implemented through the Guyana Mining School. 5. At least 30% increase over baseline of small and medium scale miners in areas identified as high priority for monitoring and enforcement comply with the environmental regulations and codes of practice. 6. 75% of small and medium-scale gold miners who participate in project seminars report an increased awareness of mining-related regulations and biodiversity issues.

Land titles issued and demarcation process completed
policy, planning and administration
Number of village maps produced and certified by sworn land surveyors (demarcation for new applications and extensions)

comment.narrative: 96 Absolute Grants have been issued. 77 Villages have been demarcated.The Ministry of Amerindian Affairs project management office does not currently manage land titling activities and have limited capacity to undertake project management responsibilities. A Special Projects Unit will be developed to undertake land titling.
7 communities and 16 villages receive Absolute Grants, and Absolute Grants for extension, respectively 13 villages and 7 village extensions demarcated
8 communities received Absolute Grants 9 villages were demarcated Cadastral surveys ongoing in 6 villages

- 20 Absolute Grants issued for villages, communities that have submitted requests.
- 47 villages to be demarcated.

- No Absolute Grant was issued in 2016. Six Villages/Communities were submitted to the Government of Guyana for no-objections. Decision is pending. - Four cadastral surveys (demarcations) were carried out in 2016 and four Certificates of Title were issued.

1. Documentation for 35 Villages and communities requesting absolute grants completed 2. Written consent for demarcation of 7 village received 3. 7 LOAs for demarcation signed 4. 7 Cadastral surveys completed 5. 35 Technical meetings held and recorded 6. 1 online database functional

description.narrative: Increased access to existing and alternative mechanism for resolve land titling disputes
policy, planning and administration
-# of persons trained with mediation skills for land related disputes - # of resolved land titling disputes that have been referred to trained mediators

comment.narrative: Mediators are not used in resolving Amerindian Land Titling Issues
232 persons trained as mediators 4 training workshops in conflict resolution
152 persons trained in FPIC and dispute resolution 4 training workshops in conflict resolution were held in Regions 2, 4 and 9
210 persons trained in mediation
A Representative Platform made up of 21 key stakeholders was convened and a Guideline for improved Amerindian land titling, Stakeholder engagement and a grievance redress mechnism was developed.
1. 150 persons trained as mediators 2. 12 mediation cases heard 3. 12 Land titling disputes and grievances resolved 4. 1 draft national ADR strategy submitted

description.narrative: Revised communication strategy
policy, planning and administration
# of communities that participate in the land titling process Extent to which revised communication strategy includes all appropriate and relevant forms of communication

comment.narrative: - 96 communities have applied and received Absolute Grants - There currently exists a draft communication strategy
Revised communication strategy, including FAQs
No revised communication strategy. Consultancy team hired and work has started.
Revised Communication Strategy tailored to include appropriate and relevant communication methods to increase awareness on Amerindian Land Titling

- Draft Amerindian land titling communication strategy and handbook were produced. - The roll-out of the Communication Strategy commenced and the following were produced and disseminated: (i) One 30 seconds Public Service Announcement on the ALT process; (ii) Two 15 mins. videos on the ALT process and results to date; (iii) 10 infographics; (iv) 10 audio recordings of FAQs in English and the nine Amerindian languages; (v) print materials including 900 bookmarks, 1000 posters, 600 brochures, and 2 retractable banners.
1. 1 Communication strategy updated 2. 35 Communities targeted 3. 50% of members of 35 communities received correct understanding on land titling and demarcation
1. 0 2. 10 3. 50% of 10 Communities
